Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: A New Model For Chemical Ecology: Integrating Chemistry, Genetics and Behavior to Understand the Role of Individual Scent in a Colonial Nesting Seabird.
Award.AbstractNarration: Personal odors can play an essential role in communication and individual recognition. Scents make be influenced by genes that are critical for immune function, including genes of the major histocompatibility complex (MHC). This study will marry chemical ecology with modern forensic science techniques establishing the Leach's storm-petrel (Oceanodroma leucorhoa), as a model system studying what appears to be a critical but little studied aspect of social interactions in birds.This long-lived, burrow-nesting species has an excellent sense of smell, making them an ideal model for this investigation. Extensive field study sites have already been established on Bon Portage Island, Nova Scotia, Canada, where over 300 breeding pairs have been genotyped for the MHC class 2B gene. The aim is to characterize the individual odor profiles of these genotyped birds using state-of-the-art chemical techniques developed for human scent discrimination. Specific research objectives are a) to test whether individual birds produce odor signatures related to their MHC-genotype, b) to determine if birds use MHC-related scent marks to label their home burrows, and c) to determine whether the scent of an individual bird is an indicator of individual quality, health and fitness, or plays a role in mate choice decisions. Showing that any species of bird uses MHC-related odors in mate choice decisions would represent a paradigm shift in how biologists think about mate choice decisions in birds, and will provide insights relevant to avian immunology and health in a wide-ranging species. Just as importantly, many species of petrels and albatrosses are facing extinction, and understanding the factors driving mate choice and colony demographics will make a valuable contribution to comprehensive management plans for endangered species. Published phenotypic/chemical or genetic data will be deposited in the Dryad Repository (http://datadryad.org/) or submitted to Genbank (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/genbank/), and deposited in Merritt Data Repository (http://www.dataone.org/software-tools/merritt-repository-service).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

Unlike in mammals, it is uncommon to observe birds performing behaviors that are readily identifiable as being guided by their sense of smell. As a result, avian olfaction was overlooked by researchers for a long time. This area of research has only recently begun to receive more attention, and as such there is still much to learn about olfaction in the lives of birds. The seabirds of the albatross and petrel family, the Procellariiformes, possess large olfactory anatomy and an exceptional sense of smell, which they rely on to find prey in the open ocean. In this project, we studied a member of this group called the Leach's storm-petrel (Oceanodroma leucorhoa) to investigate the role of olfaction in their social lives. 

At around 5 years of age, Leach's storm-petrels search for a mate that they remain with for many years, often their entire reproductive lives. Each year the pair heads to a remote island where they attempt to raise a chick in a self-constructed underground burrow. During the non-breeding season, individuals roam widely across the ocean and may not make contact with their partner for many months. Yet, when they return to breed each spring, they manage to reunite with their mate in a busy colony, a task they accomplish under the cover of darkness while lacking good night vision. Olfaction could aid in both the initial selection of a partner, an important decision in a species that mates for life, as well as in recognition of this individual over the course of their reproductive lives.

In addition to their great sense of smell, Leach's storm-petrels possess a pungent, musky body odor, which has been hypothesized to play an important role in communication in this species. In this project, we developed a novel method to identify the chemicals that make up the storm-petrel's strong body odor to determine whether socially relevant signals, such as the sex (male vs female) or identity of an individual, are present in the aroma. We found that the scent of their feathers acts much like a fingerprint to advertise the unique identity of each individual. The presence of this information in their body odor provides support to the idea that this species relies on scent for recognizing other individuals.

We also tested whether the scent of these birds could reflect indictors of their quality, which may be useful to these birds when selecting a partner. One trait that can have huge implications for an individual's reproductive success is their immune system. The Major Histocompatibility Complex, or MHC, are a set of genes found in all vertebrates that function in immune response, with different versions of these genes offering protection against different pathogens. We studied how storm-petrels select mates with respect to the MHC genes and we found that male storm-petrels prefer to partner with females who have diverse MHC genes. By doing this, males increase reproductive success, as females with the undesirable MHC genes are more likely to have failed breeding attempts.

Mate choice decisions that are tied to genetic markers are only possible if there is a physical characteristic that reflects the underlying genes, since organisms are unable to directly evaluate each other's DNA. The MHC genes an organism carries are thought to impact their body odor. We looked for evidence of this in the odor of Leach's storm-petrel and we discovered that the scent of females does advertise their MHC genotype, suggesting one potential mechanism for how males make MHC-based mate choice decisions. 

Broader Impacts:

This grant provided training opportunities for numerous students at various stages of their academic careers. In total, 10 undergraduate students participated in research activities including laboratory analyses and/or field activities at the storm-petrel colony. Additionally, four graduate students received training through this project. We disseminated the results of our research through presentations at scientific conferences and at public outreach events. The research completed as a result of this grant contributed to three peer reviewed publications and one book chapter. We anticipate several additional papers coming out in the coming months.

We participated in two professional development workshops for teachers of students in grades 6-12. The goal of the workshops was to increase teacher ocean literacy and knowledge about seabirds, and to increase teachers' ability to implement curricula that focus on seabird biology and stewardship of the environment. At each workshop, 30 secondary teachers were present for two-days of activities. We estimate that each teacher has 60 students per school year, so the potential reach of these activities is estimated to be 1,800 students in one year alone.
